name: chicagotribune
text:
George Floyd's death happened in the context of racial disparity, writes New York Times columnist David Brooks.

“It’s not an event; it’s just the daily condition of our lives ... The response to this moment will be inadequate if it’s just police reforms.” https://t.co/ymkoAzRVQn

text: Cardinal Blase Cupich said the Archdiocese will seek to have Chicago-area Catholic schools include George Floyd's killing and its aftermath in the fall curriculum. https://t.co/j1GZlaXVBP

text: Hundreds of health care workers in Chicago took a silent knee in a #WhiteCoatsforBlackLives demonstration on Friday. "It’s a human rights issue. It’s a health care issue," said one doctor. https://t.co/VaeAGcgFdG

name: chicagotribune
text: In the NFL, in which 58.9% of players last season were African American and 70.1% were people of color, the players’ fight to get their white bosses and peers to listen has been going on for years. The events of the last 2 weeks have made the calls louder. https://t.co/xjDQbphYr0

text: Mothers from two Catholic parishes in Chicago — one in a mostly black neighborhood, the other in a predominantly Latino community — marched Friday to call for unity in the struggle against violence and police brutality. https://t.co/SJcwlRSBgL

text: We don’t call this moment in the spring of 2020 “history” yet, but one day we will. Even without the clarity of retrospect, we sense we’re living through something that will shape the future in remarkable ways, writes @maryschmich  https://t.co/p5I9y8gFSd

text: “Our neighborhoods won’t be better, for anyone, until the lives of black people are better,” says a young activist from Brighton Park. https://t.co/gVffBzUttl
